close_symbols: Object table/record structure(s) and name buffer size macros (e.g. object name length/OS_MAX_API_NAME)
explanation:
To determine whether OS_TaskExit (directly or indirectly) violates the MISRA rule about string.h bounds, the analyzer must inspect all callees that can operate on object identifiers/tokens and any data they copy or compare. Provide the implementation and related helpers because they are the likely places string functions (memcpy/memmove/memset/strcpy/strncpy/strlen/etc.) could be used and could operate on object name buffers or other token fields.

- OS_TaskGetId_Impl: return value semantics and any conversion/validation of IDs; needed to see if IDs could be malformed and affect downstream string ops.
- OS_ObjectIdGetById: main routine that resolves an ID into a token; must be inspected for any string/buffer operations on object records or names.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit / OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex / OS_ObjectIdConvertToken / OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: internal helpers used by OS_ObjectIdGetById; they may perform array indexing, token conversion, or copies (use of memcpy/strncpy) that could cause out-of-bounds accesses.
- OS_TaskDetach_Impl: called with the token; must be checked for any string handling on task fields or copying of object data.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: used by TaskDetach_Impl to index into object arrays; may access name buffers or structures involved in string ops.
- OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete: finalization for delete path called with token; could perform notify/copy operations on object data (names, event payloads).
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish: used by finalize/delete; inspect for any buffer copies or string ops.
- OS_NotifyEvent: event notification may format or copy strings or payloads derived from object records; inspect for string function usage.
- OS_TaskExit_Impl: target implementation that never returns — may call further code that uses string functions; include to ensure no hidden string ops exist in the non-returning implementation.
- OS_object_token_t: full definition (fields and any pointer members) is required to know what memory/string buffers are referenced by the token and whether functions copy/compare them.
- osal_id_t, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, OS_SUCCESS: type and macro/constant definitions are required to interpret ID values, lock modes and success paths to see which code paths are taken and which helpers will be invoked (only some paths may perform string ops).
- Object table/record structure(s) and name buffer size macros (e.g. object name length/OS_MAX_API_NAME): the concrete layout and maximum sizes of name buffers or other fixed buffers are necessary to determine whether any string.h calls in the above functions could access beyond buffer bounds.

Providing these symbols (implementations, types, and buffer-size definitions) allows the next analyzer to trace the token/id through the called functions and check every use of standard string functions for potential out-of-bounds accesses.
